title: News View :: The World On Arirang
text: South Korea's capital Seoul and the surrounding areas are covered with a thick blanket of fine dust from China.It is the first time fine dust has reached such a level in Seoul since mid-July.The air quality is expected to worsen this afternoon, reaching its lowest on Tuesday morning.With that, Seoul, Incheon, and parts of Gyeonggi-do Province are carrying out new preliminary measures to reduce pollutants.These measures aim to reduce fine dust in advance two days before a high level of air pollution is expected.Starting today, from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m, all public vehicles will be forced to follow a two-day rotation system, which means that cars with license plates that end in odd numbers will be allowed on the roads only on odd days, whereas ones with even numbers will can be driven only on even days.Vehicles working to tackle African Swine Fever in the northern part of Gyeonggi-do Province will be exempt.Also, administrative agencies and public institutions will have shorter working hours, and construction sites will be required to take strict measures to prevent further dust being created.However, in the case of the preliminary reduction measures, there are no emission level 5 vehicle restrictions, and no shortened work days for the private sector.Meanwhile, the country has launched a nationwide crackdown on vehicle exhaust gas on Monday, which will run through November 15th.Seventeen provincial and city governments will enhance inspections on emissions by diesel-fuel cars, with trucks and buses being most affected.Those who do not comply with the crackdown will face fines of up to 2 million won or one,seven-hundred dollars.Those with cars whose exhaust gases exceed the permissible level will be ordered to improve the vehicle within 15 days.Such measures are deemed critical as exhaust gas is seen as the major domestic cause of fine dust while China's pollutants are the main external contributor.Lee Kyung-eun, Arirang news.
description: 한국을 대표하는 글로벌 방송! The World On Arirang!
